title: "Jax enters a defensive stance"
body: Hmm...I wasn't aware that a champion is able to leap on top of you and stun your whole team while in a "defensive" stance. Can someone explain to me why when Galio and Rammus use their defensive abilities they get slowed, but for some reason Jax gets zero ms reduction and is allowed to leap on top of me while in his "defensive" stance?

replies.body: Cuz how's he supposed to 1v5 your whole team if he can't leap around and deal tuns of damage while being unkillable? ;p

Let's be honest, in most cases, Jax isn't landing five man stuns. He's jumping on one person and taking a lot of aggro for it, and he relies entirely on his kit to be able to survive that. Galio and Rammus don't rely entirely on their W to survive their jump-in's. They're inherently tanky and build tanky. They can afford to take the aggro. That's why they have a downside.

I don't think it's fair that a tank has to suffer a 50% self slow (or whatever it is now), and Jax gets ZERO ms penalties and is allowed to jump on top of and stun you while using a defensive ability.

you can fight defensively you know, such as taking cover behind something to fire a weapon,  attacking your opponent to specifically make them less able to defend themselves, etc

in jax's case, he spins his lamp-post staff to deflect incoming attacks.  If you have watched indiana jones, I assume you remember what happens when a spinning mass suddenly impacts a target

Then don't allow him to AA during it.

If he spins his lamp in order to defend, he can't use the same lamp to attack you normally.

That's the main problem with Jax, you can't fight back, especially once he gets his spear.

did you know that one of the greatest dangers of a shield (the equipment) is that it is a large blunt object?  Even while simply holding it in front of you, you can charge into the opponent and smash your weight against the shield, likely stunning if not injuring your opponent

here's another thing, in traditional staff fighting, most weapons are nearly useless because you can disable your opponent while maintaining a distance.  In Jax's case, he can spin a staff fast enough to stop even a bullet

this is all magic stuff, now imagine a staff (solid metal) being spun at hundreds of miles per hour (a kilometer is roughly 3/5 to 2/3 of a mile)

even an ordinary staff can still cause damage while defending, let alone "the grandmaster at arms" expertise with it

that's the beauty of magic when applied to physics and real examples.  A rotating object is very stable, so if it is rotating fast enough, it creates a crushing impact and can continue rotating.  In the case with a staff, it bludgeons the opponent and the spin is resumed


#now, as for fighting jax, you're not suposed to auto attack him...ever...unless he has already burned his counterstrike or you think you can use it to your advantage.  Don't expect him NOT to use his counterstrike.  It's an adaptive ability for offense or defense.  You use abilities and defenses to your advantage.  Jax has the means to engage, but he has no poke damage, little disengage, no healing or shield and he usually burns his defensive ability to engage his target.  If he does not use counterstrike, either back away or use abilities as he is likely to trigger it when in range...

jax is a counter champ to auto-attack based champions...and some of those can even overload their way to victory.  If you want to start early, pick something geared for survival or play defensively

Jax is a duelist...he wants you to fight him because it makes him stronger.  Weaken him from a range if possible and disengage when he gets too close.  Your own crowd control can help with this.  Even a champion such as {{champion:133}}  can blind him and make her retreat, but it is a losing matchup because quinn hates targets that can stick to her...

The point is not fighting him when it's down, that applies only early-mid game.

He's a hyper carry no matter how you look at it.

I know that he maxes E last, but let's look at it this way, it has an 8 sec cd when maxed, with 40% cdr, that's 3.2s shorter, meaning 4.8s, it lasts for 2, so that's a 2.8s downtime, assuming he doesn't have a spear.

Sometimes it can even be beneficial to max it early, especially after the CD buff for his Q that he will get (hint: his rank 1 Q will have the same CD as his current rank 3 Q)

So the question is: can you kill him in the <1s the ability is down or have enough spells that he doesn't block? Because if you don't (or they are dead from the 1st stun), you ain't killing him.

He invalidates too much and that thing can be up almost permanently.

Youre assuming a lvl 18 Jax when looking at CD numbers. 

There are plenty of people who could burst Jax down during the downtime of his stun by that point in the game. And earlier (AKA the vast majority of every game played) there is A LOT more room to play with.
I did say a "not quite as there are times when maxing it second can be a good idea". How do you fight him then?

I feel like character design with intended balance should generally follow the idea that if someone has 100% of it's power invested in attack, then a defensive character should be something like 30/70% offense/defense, and the two should be able to match each other blow for blow, because defense blocks 70% of the opponent's 100% offense, leaving both at 30% offense. If that makes sense.

Of course there's a bajillion other factors to consider in here too like mobility, multi target abilities, ability uptime, strong early VS late, and such. But, gonna have to admit, there are no, or next to no tanks currently able to go blow for blow against pretty much any AD champions in 1v1's at equivalent gold.

>there are no, or next to no tanks currently able to go blow for blow against pretty much any AD champions in 1v1's at equivalent gold.

And they shouldn't. Tanks are utility champions that rely on their teammates to deal damage. They aren't designed to be 1v1 champions. A bruiser is supposed to beat a tank in 1v1 but the tank is supposed to be more useful in a team fight.
